Statement of Purpose
Application for Precog Research Lab

When Professor PK first introduced us to Precog towards the end of the DNA course, I felt an immediate and intuitive pull towards the lab—something that was hard to explain at the time. Back then, I didn’t really know what the Honors program was, what Precog actually did, or what kind of research areas it focused on. Yet, the way Precog was presented—as a space that values depth, rigor, and the courage to engage with difficult problems—resonated strongly with me.

Motivated by this initial curiosity, I began learning more about Precog by interacting with seniors and exploring the lab’s research themes in detail. As I read more about the problems Precog focuses on and its broader research philosophy, my interest became more concrete. I found myself naturally drawn to research that emphasizes understanding, reliability, and reasoning in learning-based systems, rather than treating models as opaque black boxes. Through this process, I identified the areas I am most interested in working on in depth: interpretability, natural language processing, and robustness.

One of the main reasons I wish to work with Precog is its emphasis on interpretability as a core research objective. As learning-based systems are increasingly deployed in complex and sequential decision-making environments, understanding why a system behaves in a certain way becomes crucial. I am interested in methods that uncover the structure of learned representations, provide insight into decision-making processes, and allow systematic analysis of failures. Precog’s approach to interpretability, grounded in reasoning rather than surface-level explanations, aligns closely with how I want to approach research.

I am also deeply interested in natural language processing, especially beyond conventional text-centric tasks. I am fascinated by the idea of language as a medium for abstraction, instruction, and explanation in intelligent systems. I see strong potential in using language to improve transparency and alignment, by enabling humans to specify intent, constraints, and reasoning in more natural forms. This view of NLP as an interface to reasoning and decision-making closely matches Precog’s research direction.

Robustness forms the third pillar of my interest. Real-world systems must operate under noise, uncertainty, and distribution shifts, and I am keen to study how learning-based models behave when assumptions break. I am particularly interested in building systems that degrade gracefully and can be analyzed and debugged under failure. Precog’s focus on robustness as a foundational concern, rather than an afterthought, strongly resonates with my own perspective.

My academic and project experiences have trained me to think carefully about problem structure, assumptions, and edge cases. I am comfortable working with incomplete specifications and iteratively refining systems based on observed behavior. Rather than optimizing solely for performance metrics, I try to focus on understanding underlying mechanisms and failure modes, which has naturally shaped my interest in interpretability and robustness.

At Precog, I hope to work on problems that combine interpretability, language, and robustness in learning-based decision systems. I am eager to engage deeply with challenging research problems, learn from the group, and contribute meaningfully to Precog’s efforts in building intelligent systems that are reliable, interpretable, and grounded in reasoning.

I do not believe I am the best candidate—but I do believe in persistence, patience, and consistency. Nothing in nature is perfect, not even nature itself; evolution works through countless small failures before producing something strong enough to survive. In the same way, I try to improve myself step by step. The only person I compete with is the me from yesterday. If someone does better than me today, I want that person to be me tomorrow.

My focus is always on the process, because the process is the only thing truly in our control. Output is only a by-product of effort and discipline. I believe in building strong foundations, learning deeply, and improving continuously. That is the mindset I want to bring to Precog—and the mindset I want to grow through Precog.
